page.title: 09DRAINAGE
page.content: Drainage is very important and is achieved through a series of fields and ditches and rhynes which drain into the River Brue. A dam at Bruton (12 miles upstream) and sea defences at Burnham (20 miles downstream) protect the area from flooding. Some fields can only be drained by pumping and have plastic pipes laid in the ground with small slits to let water into the top of the pipes.The pipes drain into a reservoir and the water is pumped into a ditch which flows into the river. Many rare plants grow in the area alongside the river.
